newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - T-bonds must pierce 107-28 to break free.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - T-bonds must pierce 107-28 to break free.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries are poised to push higher but must crack the key 107-28 level before bulls regain the upper hand, technical analysts said on Thursday.
"The market could stretch higher, but it won't until it pushes through 107-28," said Elizabeth Miller, technical analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "Then we could see it up a point."

The T-bond future has found the 107-28 level particularly hard to crack over the last few weeks. The market bounced off a high of 107-28 on April 9, 107-27 on April 15 and 107-23 on Wednesday. By 1139 GMT it was up 7/32 at 107-22. The 30-year long bond was at 94.10 to yield 7.08 percent.
Bill Westgate, vice-president at HSBC Securities here was bullish on Treasuries.
"We've got the beginnings of early technical evidence supporting (a move up) and it's time to get involved," he said.

"I think the trend is turning now and it will therefore now move into an uptrend," he said, adding the fact the market bounced off its lows for the second day on Wednesday showed it was firmly rejecting lower levels.
A number of secondary technical indicators, useful in confirming any major technical price breaks, back up suggestions the mood in T-bonds has lightened lately.
Stochastics -- or momentum indicators that suggest how much strength is behind a market move -- have turned bullish, said analysts.

A bullish crossover occurs when the percentage K (the ratio of the differnce between the current price and the low of the range, compared to the magnitude of the overall range) is trading above the percentage D (a three-bar moving average of the percentage K values).
Miller said modified stochastics show the percentage K at 48.33 and the percentage D at 32.51.

"I agree that there is a buy signal given by modified stochastics -- but unless it's above the 50 percent area it's not a massively strong signal," she said, adding it was a subsidiary indicator, second to the price level.
Stavros Loizou, manager of strategic trading at Fuji Bank in London, also expected the market to move higher and agreed the main target was at 107-28.
"I would go with the upside," he said.
On the downside he saw good support at 106-29, Wednesday's low then at 106-23,24 the breakout point from the April 14 high.
Westgate said the relative strength indicator had put in a bullish divergence, which, with the stochastics, was supportive.
